datafield.subfield: Sermones de Tempore et de Sanctis; Summa Sermonum (fragment).
Wyly, Bryan Weston. Report on Article Burgess 035.
From the bequest of Edward Sanford Burgess (Jan 19 1915) Purchase from Dr. Giuseppe Martini.
Item cataloged from existing description by C. Pierce and J. Fox, and in hand by Erika Milo and Ian Scott, July/August 2018.
All requests for permission to quote or publish from manuscripts must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections & University Archives.

Contained in this volume are the fragmentary sermons of Iohannes Halgrinus de AbbatisVilla (died 1237), A French philosopher and writer of Sermons, as well as Papal legate to the court of Fredric II of Spain & Portugal, and Cardinal of Sabina(1227). He has been described as a theological follower of Petrus Cantor and Cardinal Stephen Langton. He studied in Paris with Hugolino of Ostia (Pope Gregory IX) at the University of Paris.

Collation: small folio (286 x 215 mm) in gatherings of 8 with roman numeral signatures and folio numbers, with the exception signed XXII^15-1 (for further clarification seek report by Bryan Weston Wyly). In this fragment the first page number is [CXXXVII] on folio 1, the first quire signature is XVIII on f7r and follow to XXIIII. Cataloging numeration follows Wyly diagram, f1r is f137r, f61v (final) is f192v. The red stain on the fol 141v indicates a capitulum on the adjacent missing folio.
Layout: 2 columns of 34 lines upon an area of 212x150mm. Pricking has been trimmed but ruling by lead point is visible.

Script: Gothic Minuscule Bookhand. "The script of this codex gives the general impression of an English or Northern French Gothic minuscule: the minimed letter i, u, m and n are clubbed (the u and i in debuit on f19r, column 1, line 28), letters are quite angular (the right stroke in m and n); ascenders and descenders are short (the l in calice and the p in portauit on f19r, column 1, line 1);the back of the unical d fuses to the back of the e (mordebit on f18v, column 2, line 16) as does the bowl of p with the back of e in opera in f18v, column 2, line 33. This script also has a number of features that distinguish it [...]; the clubbing on i,u,m and n is much more pronounced (in uitro on f18v, column 2, line 15), the ascenders are forked--a v-shaped stroke at the top of the ascender--(the b's in bibere on f19r, column 2, line 25), (÷) is used for est (f19r, column 2, line 2), the writing is more compressed, and a straight ling is the common mark of abbreviation (manuu on f19r column 1, line 3)." Pierce & Fox. Also of note in the script is the customary very slight bend which defines minims, ascenders and descenders. Also to accompany the use of the augmented obelus (division symbol), with comma replacing the lower tittle, is the frequent application of the tironian nota, clearly not representing the same thing (see f19r, column 2, line 5, with both symbols adjacent). As well as the isolated occurrence of a stroked nota, or perhaps capital Zed, in the proceeding lines of f19r, column 2.
Decoration: Each major section of the text begins with alternating Blue/Red initial with opposite colour tracery. Sermon headings are rubricated.

Binding: Vellum over boards labelled "the Gospels - MS. XII(I) century" on spine in gilt letters. Third 'I' with gilt having been obliterated. (Third 'I' without any remaining gilt, helping explain why previous catalogues had this work misrepresented.) Inside rear cover expresses clearly watermark "MICHALLET," upon the same material of flyleaves and current, later binding.
Shelfmark: Eugene, OR, Special Collections and University Archives, University of Oregon, MS 035.
